depth_guidance.deep: Complete lexical archaeology: every significant term traced to its origin (author coinage, borrowing, repurposing), terminological clusters mapped to intellectual traditions, diachronic assessment of which terms are stable vs. evolving, and precursor analysis identifying what earlier vocabulary this terminology likely replaced or refined
depth_guidance.standard: Full vocabulary map: coined terms with likely precursors, repurposed terms with standard vs. author meanings, key oppositions with what analytical work they do, and assessment of which terms carry unearned authority
depth_guidance.surface: List the 5-10 most distinctive terms with brief definitions and note any obviously coined vocabulary

analytical_dimensions.description: The complete lexical inventory of the work: terms coined by the author, standard terms used non-standardly, key oppositions that structure the argument, and precursor terms that might have been used for the same concept in earlier work. Vocabulary is the most reliable genealogical tracer -- authors change their arguments, but their distinctive terms persist.
probing_questions: What terms does the author coin or use distinctively?
Which standard terms are given non-standard meanings?
What key oppositions structure the argument (e.g., structure/agency, system/lifeworld)?
Which terms feel 'settled' without adequate justification in this text -- are they borrowing authority from elsewhere?
What precursor terms might have existed for the same concept in earlier work?
Are there terminological clusters that suggest a particular intellectual tradition?

depth_guidance.deep: Complete methodological fingerprint: every significant evidence type and analytical move catalogued with textual examples, cross-referenced with intellectual traditions that favor these methods, assessment of which moves are conscious choices vs. unreflective habits, and comparison with the author's stated methodology (if any) to detect mismatches between practice and self-description
depth_guidance.standard: Full methodological profile: evidence types with assessment of epistemic commitments, argumentative structure, recurring moves with examples, and what counts as evidence -- revealing the author's implicit theory of knowledge
depth_guidance.surface: Identify the primary evidence types and 2-3 recurring analytical moves

analytical_dimensions.description: How the author characteristically argues: what counts as evidence, what logical structures recur, what analytical moves are habitual. Methodological signatures are the most persistent feature of an author's intellectual identity -- they change arguments, switch topics, revise positions, but their WAY OF ARGUING remains recognizable across decades.
probing_questions: What types of evidence does the author rely on (historical narrative, data, theoretical derivation, analogy, case study, thought experiment)?
What is the characteristic argumentative structure (dialectical, cumulative, abductive, deductive, genealogical)?
What analytical moves recur (reframing X as Y, appeals to structural necessity, deriving from historical narrative, immanent critique)?
What counts as sufficient evidence for a claim -- what are the author's epistemological commitments?
Are there signature rhetorical patterns that function as analytical tools?

depth_guidance.deep: Complete metaphor archaeology: every significant metaphor traced to its likely origin, assessed for maturity (fresh coinage vs. polished through reuse), mapped to the frameworks it supports, analyzed for what it reveals and conceals about the subject matter, and cross-referenced with other authors who use the same metaphor differently
depth_guidance.standard: Full metaphor inventory: each metaphor with source domain, analytical weight (heavy/moderate/decorative), which frameworks use it, what it imports from the source domain, and whether the author treats it as literal
depth_guidance.surface: List the 3-5 most prominent metaphors with their source domains and analytical weight

analytical_dimensions.description: Metaphors and analogies that do real analytical work in the text -- not decorative language but structural elements that shape what can be thought. A metaphor that carries heavy argumentative weight is a genealogical prize: it probably evolved from simpler forms in earlier work, gaining analytical power as the author refined it.
probing_questions: What metaphors or analogies carry heavy argumentative weight -- doing real analytical work, not just illustration?
Which metaphors are borrowed from other domains, and what do they import along with themselves?
Are any metaphors treated as literal -- has the author forgotten they are metaphors?
Do metaphors cluster by framework, suggesting they evolved together?
Which metaphors feel 'mature' -- polished through repeated use -- vs. tentative?

depth_guidance.deep: Complete framing archaeology: how the framing positions the work within its field, what alternative framings were available but not used (and why), how the framing constrains what conclusions are reachable, the politics of the framing (who benefits from this way of posing the question), and comparison with how the author has framed similar problems in other works
depth_guidance.standard: Full framing landscape: problem framing with foregrounded and backgrounded aspects, novelty claims, continuity claims, opponent/ally map, and assessment of what the framing suppresses
depth_guidance.surface: Identify the central framing, what it emphasizes, and who the main allies/opponents are

analytical_dimensions.description: How the work frames its central problem, what it foregrounds and backgrounds, and how the author positions themselves relative to allies and opponents. Framing is never neutral: every presentation emphasizes some aspects and renders others invisible. Tracking how framing changes across an author's works reveals strategic evolution.
probing_questions: How is the central problem or question framed -- what does this framing make visible and invisible?
What does the author claim is novel or original in their contribution?
What continuity with prior work does the author claim?
Who are the intellectual opponents -- what is the author positioned against?
Who are the intellectual allies -- whose authority is borrowed?
What does the framing suppress -- qualifications, alternatives, complications that are absent?

depth_guidance.deep: Full architectural analysis: complete dependency graph between frameworks, load-bearing assessment (what collapses if X is removed), competing and complementary relationships, emergent frameworks with their synthesis logic, and assessment of architectural coherence (is the framework ensemble well-integrated or ad hoc?)
depth_guidance.standard: Map the framework architecture: foundational vs. dependent vs. peripheral, competing frameworks, complementary pairs, and emergent syntheses
depth_guidance.surface: Identify the 2-3 foundational frameworks and their main dependencies

analytical_dimensions.description: The structural relationships between frameworks: which are foundational, which are dependent, which compete, which are complementary. The architecture reveals the load-bearing elements -- remove a foundational framework and everything above it collapses.
probing_questions: Which frameworks are foundational -- everything else depends on them?
Which frameworks are peripheral -- could be removed without structural damage?
Do any frameworks compete with each other -- offering alternative explanations for the same phenomena?
Are there emergent frameworks synthesized from multiple component frameworks?
What is the relationship between theoretical frameworks and applied/practical ones?

depth_guidance.deep: Full cross-domain analysis: every significant import traced to its source tradition, assessment of how adaptation changed the original concept, analysis of what the source domain's assumptions smuggle into the current argument, and mapping of the author's intellectual formation as revealed by their cross-domain toolkit
depth_guidance.standard: Map domain crossings: source field, what was imported, how it was adapted, whether acknowledged, and whether the import is productive or distorting
depth_guidance.surface: Note the 2-3 most significant cross-domain imports and their source fields

analytical_dimensions.description: Where concepts, methods, or structural analogies are imported from other fields. Each crossing is a potential genealogical thread -- it reveals where the author was trained, what they read, and what shapes their thinking below conscious awareness. An economist doing political theory doesn't just have economic ideas; they have an economic WAY OF THINKING.
probing_questions: What concepts, methods, or analogies are imported from other fields?
How have imports been adapted for the current domain -- what was changed and what was preserved?
Are the cross-domain origins acknowledged or invisible to the author?
Do imports create productive insights or misleading analogies?
What intellectual training or background do the domain crossings reveal?

depth_scaling.deep: Full lexical archaeology tracing every significant term to its origin, mapping terminological clusters to traditions, identifying precursors, and assessing diachronic stability
depth_scaling.standard: Complete map of coined, repurposed, and borrowed terms with assessment of inferential profiles and authority sources
depth_scaling.surface: Lists 5-10 distinctive terms with brief definitions, flags obvious coinages

capabilities.description: Build a complete lexical inventory: coined terms, repurposed terms, key oppositions, and genealogical tracers
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability performs lexical archaeology on an intellectual work, excavating not just what terms mean in the current text but what genealogical work they do. Following Brandom's insight that vocabularies are inferentially articulated—each term comes bundled with commitment patterns—this extraction identifies coined terms (new vocabulary introduced to carve conceptual space), repurposed terms (existing vocabulary given non-standard inferential profiles), and key oppositions (conceptual pairs that structure the argumentative field). The goal is not a dictionary but a map of conceptual authority: which terms carry weight earned in this text versus borrowed from elsewhere, which terminological choices reveal intellectual lineage, which vocabularies mark the author as trained in particular traditions.

This capability is foundational for the entire engine. The vocabulary map becomes the search signature for downstream semantic constellation analysis—you cannot track how terms migrate across works without first knowing which terms matter. It feeds the methodological signature by revealing disciplinary markers (economists don't just use different concepts than sociologists; they use different vocabularies for the SAME concepts). It enables domain crossing detection by identifying when technical vocabulary from one field appears in another. Without vocabulary extraction, all subsequent analysis lacks targets.

The sophisticated version distinguishes between three types of unearned authority: terms borrowing from the author's own prior work (requiring diachronic genealogy), terms borrowing from a recognized tradition (requiring synchronic mapping to schools of thought), and terms that feel established but have no clear pedigree (the most interesting case—possible coinages that have been naturalized through rhetorical confidence). A naive extraction lists important words; a sophisticated one reveals intellectual debts.
indicators: Terms introduced with explicit definition or stipulation ('By X I mean...', 'Let us call this...', 'I propose the concept...')
Standard terms used in non-standard ways, especially when the author marks the departure ('Unlike the usual sense of X...', 'X in my sense...')
Key oppositions structuring arguments (repeated either/or framings, contrastive pairs doing analytical work)
Terms appearing without justification but carrying heavy argumentative weight—signs of borrowed authority
Clusters of specialized vocabulary from identifiable disciplines or theoretical traditions

intellectual_grounding.method: Brandom argues vocabularies are not mere labels but nodes in inferential networks—to introduce a term is to introduce patterns of what follows from what. This capability treats vocabulary extraction as inferential profile mapping, asking not just 'what does X mean?' but 'what inferential commitments does using X incur?'

depth_scaling.deep: Complete fingerprint of every significant methodological pattern, cross-referenced with traditions, distinguishing conscious choices from unreflective habits, and comparing stated versus practiced methodology
depth_scaling.standard: Full profile of evidence types, argumentative structures, recurring moves with examples, and implicit epistemological commitments
depth_scaling.surface: Identifies primary evidence types and 2-3 recurring analytical moves

capabilities.description: Characterize the author's argumentative fingerprint: evidence types, logical structures, recurring moves, epistemological commitments
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability extracts the author's argumentative fingerprint—the persistent methodological habits that constitute their intellectual identity across topics and positions. Drawing on Lakatos's insight that research programmes are distinguished not by their content but by their heuristics (their characteristic ways of generating and testing claims), this profiling asks: what counts as evidence for this author? What logical structures recur? What analytical moves feel habitual rather than chosen? The output is a methodological signature that persists even when the author changes fields, revises positions, or addresses new problems. An economist doing political theory doesn't just import economic concepts; they import economic WAYS OF ARGUING—preferences for formal models over narrative, optimization assumptions, equilibrium thinking.

This capability is critical for genealogical analysis because methodological signatures are the most stable element of intellectual identity. Authors abandon frameworks, revise positions, even repudiate earlier work, but they rarely change their fundamental way of arguing. The profile feeds the architectural analysis by revealing which frameworks are truly load-bearing versus decorative (the frameworks that align with the author's methodological habits do the real work). It enables comparison across an author's corpus, detecting when a methodological shift signals genuine intellectual transformation versus surface revision. It reveals implicit epistemological commitments—what the author treats as sufficient warrant often betrays deeper philosophical assumptions than their explicit methodology statements.

The sophisticated version distinguishes between conscious methodological choices (announced, defended, explicitly theoretical) and unreflective habits (recurring patterns the author may not recognize as methodological). It detects mismatches between stated methodology and actual practice—the historian who claims to avoid counterfactuals but structures every causal argument around implicit comparison with what didn't happen. It identifies signature moves that function as analytical tools: the characteristic Foucauldian reversal (taking what seems like progress and reading it as power consolidation), the Marxian derivation (showing how surface phenomena emerge necessarily from deeper structures).
indicators: Recurring evidence types (heavy reliance on historical narrative, preference for formal models, repeated use of thought experiments, appeal to case studies)
Characteristic argumentative structures (dialectical patterns, cumulative building, abductive inference chains, genealogical tracing)
Signature analytical moves that appear across different arguments (reframing, deriving, immanent critique, structural necessity appeals)
Explicit methodological statements that can be compared with actual practice to detect gaps
Patterns in what counts as sufficient warrant—when does the author stop arguing and consider a claim established?

intellectual_grounding.method: Lakatos argues research programmes are identified by their heuristics—not their specific claims but their characteristic ways of generating problems, devising solutions, and responding to anomalies. This capability treats authors as embodiments of research programmes, extracting the heuristic patterns that structure their argumentative practice.

depth_scaling.deep: Complete archaeology of every significant metaphor, tracing origins, assessing maturity, mapping to frameworks, analyzing what each reveals and conceals, and comparing with other authors' uses
depth_scaling.standard: Full inventory of significant metaphors with source domains, analytical weight assessment, framework associations, and literal/heuristic status
depth_scaling.surface: Lists 3-5 prominent metaphors with source domains and rough assessment of analytical weight

capabilities.description: Identify metaphors doing analytical work, assess their weight, trace their likely origins and maturity
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability identifies metaphors and analogies that do genuine analytical work—not rhetorical decoration but structural elements that shape what can be thought. Following Cassirer's analysis of symbolic forms as constitutive of thought (metaphors don't illustrate pre-existing ideas; they enable certain ideas to be formulated at all), this tracking distinguishes load-bearing metaphors from ornamental ones. A load-bearing metaphor imports an entire structural logic from its source domain: treating the mind as a computer doesn't just illustrate cognitive science, it commits you to particular claims about information processing, storage, and retrieval. The goal is to map which metaphors are doing real work, what they import along with themselves, and which ones have been naturalized to the point where the author no longer recognizes them as metaphors.

Metaphors are genealogical gold because they evolve visibly across an author's work. A metaphor introduced tentatively in an early paper ('Let me try thinking of X as like Y...') becomes confident in later work ('X is essentially Y'), gaining analytical weight through repeated deployment and refinement. Tracking metaphor maturity—fresh coinages versus polished through reuse—reveals which ideas are new versus which have been long incubating. This capability feeds domain crossing detection (metaphors are the primary vehicle for importing concepts across fields) and supports architectural analysis (frameworks often cluster around shared root metaphors). It reveals what the author finds thinkable: the metaphors you habitually use constrain what conclusions you can reach.

The sophisticated version asks not just what metaphors are present but what they make visible and invisible. The social contract metaphor foregrounds voluntary agreement and backgrounds coercion; the organic society metaphor foregrounds holistic interdependence and backgrounds individual agency. It tracks whether the author treats metaphors as heuristic tools (consciously deployed, explicitly provisional) or as literal descriptions (the metaphorical origin forgotten). It identifies metaphor clusters that suggest frameworks evolved together, sharing a common root image that structures multiple concepts simultaneously.
indicators: Extended analogies that structure entire arguments or sections (sustained comparison across multiple features)
Metaphors from other domains carrying technical implications (computational metaphors importing information theory, biological metaphors importing evolutionary logic)
Repeated metaphors across different contexts suggesting they are load-bearing rather than decorative
Metaphors treated as literal—claims that X 'is' Y rather than 'is like' Y, suggesting naturalization
Competing metaphors for the same phenomenon, revealing tension in how the author conceptualizes it

intellectual_grounding.method: Cassirer argues symbolic forms (including metaphors) don't represent pre-existing reality but constitute what can be thought—they are not illustrative but generative. This capability treats metaphors as analytical infrastructure, asking what thought-structures each metaphor enables and constrains.

depth_scaling.deep: Complete framing archaeology: how framing positions the work in its field, alternative framings not chosen, constraint analysis (what conclusions the framing rules out), politics of framing, and cross-work comparison
depth_scaling.standard: Full landscape of problem framing, foregrounded/backgrounded aspects, novelty/continuity claims, ally/opponent map, and identified suppressions
depth_scaling.surface: Identifies central framing, main emphases, and primary allies/opponents

capabilities.description: Map how the work frames its problem, what it foregrounds and backgrounds, and how the author positions relative to allies and opponents
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability maps how the work frames its central problem—what it foregrounds, backgrounds, and suppresses—and how the author positions themselves within the intellectual field. Drawing on Kuhn's insight that paradigms define not just what counts as an answer but what counts as a legitimate question, framing analysis asks: what does this way of posing the problem make thinkable? What alternatives are rendered invisible? How does the framing constrain the space of possible conclusions? Every framing is a strategic choice (conscious or not) that emphasizes some aspects while rendering others peripheral. Tracking how an author frames problems across works reveals strategic evolution—learning what questions get traction, what framings attract allies, what moves neutralize opponents.

This capability is essential for understanding the politics of intellectual work. The author's novelty claims reveal what they consider valuable contributions; their continuity claims reveal which traditions they seek membership in; their ally/opponent map reveals which debates they consider themselves participating in. The framing also reveals suppressions—qualifications not made, alternatives not considered, complications not addressed. These absences are often more revealing than presences: what an author doesn't feel they need to argue against tells you what they assume their audience already accepts. The framing feeds architectural analysis (foundational frameworks typically appear in the problem framing itself) and enables comparison across an author's work (tracking whether they consistently frame problems the same way or strategically adapt).

The sophisticated version asks what alternative framings were available but not chosen, and why. It analyzes the politics of framing: whose interests are served by this way of posing the question? What audiences does this framing address or exclude? It detects when framing does hidden argumentative work—when the way a problem is posed already presupposes part of the answer. It compares stated framing with actual argumentative practice, detecting cases where the announced problem and the problem actually addressed diverge.
indicators: Explicit problem statements, especially in introductions ('The question this book addresses...', 'The central puzzle is...')
Novelty claims marking what the author considers their original contribution ('Unlike previous accounts...', 'What has been missed is...')
Continuity claims positioning the work within traditions ('Building on X...', 'Following Y...', 'In the spirit of Z...')
Opponent identification—who the author argues against, what positions are rejected
Absent qualifications—dogs that don't bark, alternatives not considered, complications not addressed despite seeming relevant

intellectual_grounding.method: Kuhn argues paradigms don't just provide answers but define what counts as a legitimate question—normal science operates within question-spaces structured by paradigmatic exemplars. This capability treats problem framing as paradigmatic work, asking what question-space the framing opens and closes.

depth_scaling.deep: Complete dependency graph, load-bearing assessment via counterfactual removal, competing and complementary relationships, synthesis logic, and coherence evaluation
depth_scaling.standard: Full architectural map: foundational vs. dependent vs. peripheral, competing frameworks, complementary pairs, emergent syntheses
depth_scaling.surface: Identifies 2-3 foundational frameworks and their main dependencies

capabilities.description: Reveal the structural relationships between frameworks: foundational, dependent, competing, complementary, emergent
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability reveals the structural relationships between frameworks—which are foundational (everything depends on them), which are peripheral (could be removed without collapse), which compete (offering alternative explanations), which are complementary (mutually reinforcing). Following Lakatos's distinction between the hard core of a research programme (protected from refutation) and its protective belt (adjusted under empirical pressure), architectural mapping identifies load-bearing elements versus disposable scaffolding. A foundational framework is one whose removal causes cascading collapse; a peripheral framework can be excised without structural damage. The output is a dependency graph showing what rests on what.

This analysis is critical for genealogical work because it reveals which frameworks are truly constitutive of the author's thought versus which are borrowed tools used opportunistically. When tracking an author's intellectual development, changes to foundational frameworks signal genuine transformation; changes to peripheral frameworks are tactical adjustments. The architecture also reveals synthesis patterns—emergent frameworks built by combining component frameworks, showing how authors integrate diverse influences into coherent positions. It enables comparative analysis: two authors might deploy the same frameworks but arrange them differently, with different elements foundational.

The sophisticated version performs load-bearing assessment by asking counterfactually: if we removed framework X, what would collapse? It distinguishes between logical dependence (framework B presupposes claims made by framework A) and rhetorical dependence (framework B needs A's authority to be convincing). It identifies tensions—competing frameworks that generate contradictory implications, revealing unresolved theoretical problems. It detects when the architecture is well-integrated (frameworks fit together systematically) versus ad hoc (frameworks selected opportunistically without concern for coherence).
indicators: Frameworks explicitly identified as foundational or presupposed ('The argument rests on...', 'Starting from the assumption that...', 'Everything that follows depends on...')
Frameworks repeatedly invoked across different arguments, suggesting they are load-bearing
Competing explanations for the same phenomenon, revealing framework tension
Synthesis claims where the author explicitly combines multiple frameworks ('Drawing on both X and Y...', 'Integrating A with B...')
Frameworks that appear early in the text and structure what follows versus frameworks introduced locally for specific arguments

intellectual_grounding.method: Lakatos distinguishes research programmes' hard core (fundamental assumptions protected from refutation) from their protective belt (auxiliary hypotheses adjusted under pressure). This capability treats frameworks as differentially protected, mapping which are core (foundational, load-bearing) versus peripheral (adjustable, disposable).

depth_scaling.deep: Complete cross-domain analysis: every significant import traced to source, adaptation analysis, assumption-smuggling assessment, mapping of author's intellectual formation via their cross-domain toolkit
depth_scaling.standard: Full map of domain crossings: source field, what was imported, adaptation, acknowledgment status, productivity assessment
depth_scaling.surface: Notes 2-3 most significant cross-domain imports and their source fields

capabilities.description: Identify concepts, methods, and analogies imported from other fields, and assess what intellectual formation they reveal
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability identifies when concepts, methods, or structural analogies are imported from other fields, and analyzes what these crossings reveal about the author's intellectual formation. Every domain crossing is a genealogical tracer: an economist doing political theory doesn't just happen to use game theory—their training shaped them to see strategic interaction everywhere. A literary critic using psychoanalytic concepts brings not just Freudian vocabulary but Freudian assumptions about interpretation (everything is symptomatic, meaning is hidden, surface appearances deceive). Following the insight that disciplinary training operates partly through unconscious habit formation, this detection asks: what does the author's cross-domain toolkit reveal about where they were trained, what they read, what shapes their thinking below conscious awareness?

Domain crossings do double work: they import analytical power (concepts honed in one domain often illuminate another) but also smuggle assumptions. When rational choice theory crosses from economics to political science, it imports not just utility maximization but methodological individualism, preference stability assumptions, and consequentialist ethics. The sophisticated analysis asks whether crossings are productive (genuinely illuminating the target domain) or distorting (imposing inappropriate structure). It tracks whether the author acknowledges the crossing (explicit borrowing with reflection on appropriateness) or whether imports operate invisibly (the author doesn't recognize their assumptions as domain-specific).

This capability is particularly valuable for revealing intellectual formation that the author might not consciously recognize. A philosopher trained in analytic philosophy and later working in continental philosophy doesn't just switch vocabularies—their analytic training shows in their argumentative style, their standards of rigor, their preference for clear definitions over suggestive ambiguity. These stylistic markers are domain crossings of method rather than content. The capability feeds back into vocabulary extraction (technical terms from other fields) and methodological profiling (domain-specific argument styles).
indicators: Technical vocabulary from other disciplines appearing without definition (suggesting the author assumes that conceptual framework)
Methods characteristic of other fields (formal modeling in humanistic work, hermeneutic interpretation in social science, experimental design in philosophy)
Structural analogies importing logic from other domains ('The economy is like an ecosystem', 'Society is like a text')
Citation patterns showing significant engagement with literature from other fields
Argumentative moves characteristic of other disciplines (proof-styles from mathematics, causal identification strategies from economics, genealogical tracing from history)

intellectual_grounding.method: Kuhn argues scientific training operates through exemplars—paradigmatic problem-solutions that teach not just content but ways of seeing. This capability treats domain crossings as traces of disciplinary matrices, asking what ways-of-seeing from other fields the author imports along with specific concepts.

shares_with.domain_crossing_map: Cross-field imports revealing intellectual formation and implicit assumptions
shares_with.framework_architecture: Structural relationships between frameworks -- dependency and load-bearing analysis
shares_with.framing_landscape: Problem framing, novelty/continuity claims, ally/opponent map -- strategic positioning data
shares_with.genealogical_hints: Signals that frameworks have histories beyond the current text -- settled claims, habitual moves, mature metaphors
shares_with.metaphor_inventory: Metaphors with source domains and analytical weight -- tracers for cross-work evolution tracking
shares_with.methodological_fingerprint: Evidence types, argumentative structure, recurring moves -- persistent identity markers
shares_with.vocabulary_profile: Coined terms, repurposed terms, key oppositions -- the lexical fingerprint for downstream genealogical matching

depth_levels.description: Extract the dominant frameworks, key vocabulary, and most prominent metaphors with brief characterization

passes.description:
A single sweep across the text to capture the dominant conceptual
landscape. Prioritize the most visible frameworks, the 5-10 most
distinctive vocabulary items, the primary methodological pattern,
and the 3-5 metaphors doing the heaviest analytical work. For
architecture and domain crossings, note only what is immediately
apparent -- foundational frameworks and obvious cross-field imports.
The goal is a rapid but honest sketch, not exhaustive coverage.
passes.label: Framework Scan

depth_levels.suitable_for: Quick assessment, policy documents, non-academic texts, preliminary scoping before deeper analysis

depth_levels.description: Full vocabulary map with genealogical tracers, complete methodological profile, metaphor inventory with analytical weight, framing landscape with positioning, and framework architecture with dependencies

passes.description:
Systematic inventory of the four independent dimensions. Build the
full vocabulary map with coined terms, repurposed terms, key
oppositions, and genealogical tracers. Profile the methodological
signature including evidence types, argumentative structure, and
recurring analytical moves. Catalog metaphors with their source
domains and analytical weight. Map the framing landscape: problem
framing, novelty/continuity claims, ally/opponent positioning.
This pass produces the raw material that architectural analysis
requires.
passes.label: Lexical and Methodological Inventory

passes.description:
With the vocabulary map and methodological profile in hand, now
map the structural relationships between frameworks. Identify
which frameworks are foundational, dependent, peripheral, or
competing. Trace domain crossings using the vocabulary inventory
as evidence -- cross-field imports often hide in borrowed terminology.
Assess how adaptations changed the original concepts and what
assumptions they smuggled in. The architecture should reveal load-
bearing elements whose removal would collapse the argument.
passes.label: Architectural Mapping

depth_levels.suitable_for: Most academic texts, standard genealogy target profiling, author with 3-5 prior works

depth_levels.description: Complete lexical archaeology with every significant term traced to origin, full methodological fingerprint cross-referenced with intellectual traditions, metaphor maturity assessment, framing politics analysis, exhaustive framework architecture with load-bearing assessment, and comprehensive domain crossing analysis revealing the author's complete intellectual formation

passes.description:
Exhaustive inventory with no significance threshold. Every coined
term, every repurposed term, every terminological cluster traced
to its intellectual tradition. Full methodological fingerprint
cross-referenced with traditions that favor these methods, including
mismatches between stated and practiced methodology. Complete
metaphor archaeology: maturity assessment (fresh vs. polished
through reuse), what each metaphor reveals and conceals. Framing
politics: what alternative framings were available but not used,
who benefits from the chosen framing. Leave nothing for later
passes to discover at this level.
passes.label: Exhaustive Lexical and Methodological Excavation

passes.description:
Build the complete structural skeleton of the work's conceptual
apparatus. Map every dependency between frameworks -- foundational,
dependent, peripheral, competing, complementary, emergent. Perform
load-bearing assessment: what collapses if each framework is
removed? Trace every cross-domain import to its source tradition,
assess how adaptation changed the original, and map what the source
domain's assumptions smuggle into the current argument. The
architecture should be detailed enough to serve as a structural
blueprint of the author's intellectual edifice.
passes.label: Structural Architecture and Cross-Domain Tracing

passes.description:
Synthesize all dimensions into the complete target profile that
downstream engines will consume. Cross-reference vocabulary clusters
with architectural dependencies -- do terminological families align
with framework hierarchies? Assess how the methodological signature
constrains which frameworks can be deployed. Evaluate the coherence
of the whole ensemble: does the conceptual architecture support the
framing claims? Do domain crossings enrich or distort the framework
architecture? Produce genealogical implications: what does this
profile predict about the author's intellectual formation, and what
should downstream engines (semantic constellation, inferential
commitment mapper) look for?
passes.label: Integrative Profile Synthesis

depth_levels.suitable_for: Dense philosophical works, prolific authors with extensive prior work, foundational profiling for major genealogy studies

key_concepts.definition: A diachronically extended theoretical structure with a stable hard core of unfalsifiable commitments, a protective belt of modifiable auxiliary hypotheses, and heuristics directing theory development. Used by this engine to identify the persistent analytical commitments that unify an author's work across texts while allowing methodological adaptation.
key_concepts.name: research_programme

key_concepts.definition: A disciplinary matrix of shared exemplars, symbolic generalizations, values, and metaphysical commitments that determines what counts as legitimate problems, solutions, and evidence within a research community. This engine uses it to analyze how analytical frameworks function as gestalt-determining structures that render certain phenomena visible while others become unthinkable.
key_concepts.name: paradigm

key_concepts.definition: A structured set of theoretical terms that confer expressive power and carry inferential commitments, not merely labeling phenomena but enabling certain forms of analysis while foreclosing others. The engine tracks vocabulary as the primary tracer of intellectual lineage—distinctive terminological choices reveal training, influence, and framework commitments.
key_concepts.name: vocabulary

key_concepts.definition: The characteristic argumentative moves, evidential standards, and analytical habits that persist across an author's work, functioning as a recognizable style of intellectual practice. This engine identifies signatures as expressions of deeper programmatic commitments—habitual moves that reveal the author's intellectual formation and framework loyalty.
key_concepts.name: methodological_signature

key_concepts.definition: Figurative language that does genuine analytical work by structuring how phenomena are conceptualized, what relations become visible, and what inferences are licensed—not decorative but constitutive of the framework itself. The engine treats sustained metaphors as framework-carriers that often migrate across texts, making them valuable genealogical tracers.
key_concepts.name: metaphor_as_argument

key_concepts.definition: The selection and organization of analytical focus that determines what aspects of a phenomenon are foregrounded as central while others are backgrounded or rendered invisible. This engine analyzes framing choices as revealing framework commitments—what must be explained versus what can be taken as given exposes the author's theoretical priorities.
key_concepts.name: framing

key_concepts.definition: The migration of analytical frameworks, vocabularies, or methodological approaches from one disciplinary or topical domain to another, often adapting the framework to new phenomena. The engine tracks domain crossings as moments of framework innovation where genealogical threads become visible—the source domain reveals lineage while adaptations show original contribution.
key_concepts.name: domain_crossing

key_concepts.definition: Textual markers that signal intellectual lineage: unjustified terms assuming shared vocabulary, methodological moves that feel habitual rather than argued for, citations that gesture toward authority, or framework choices that seem overdetermined by prior commitments. These hints guide downstream engines toward the intellectual relationships that constitute the author's formation.
key_concepts.name: genealogical_hint

primary.description: Imre Lakatos (1922-1974), philosopher of mathematics and science, developed the methodology of scientific research programmes as an alternative to both Kuhnian paradigms and Popperian falsificationism. His framework is primary here because it treats intellectual frameworks themselves as historical entities with internal logic (hard cores, protective belts, heuristics) that evolve through time while maintaining methodological identity—precisely what this engine must track when analyzing how analytical scaffolding persists and mutates across an author's corpus.
primary.name: lakatos

secondary.description: Thomas Kuhn (1922-1996), historian and philosopher of science, introduced the concept of paradigms as disciplinary matrices that determine what counts as a problem, solution, and evidence within scientific communities. For this engine, Kuhn's attention to incommensurability and gestalt shifts illuminates how different analytical frameworks render certain phenomena visible while others become literally unthinkable—the framing choices that structure what any given conceptual apparatus can see. His work on scientific vocabulary as theory-laden complements Lakatos by showing how terminological choices carry entire worldviews.
secondary.name: kuhn

secondary.description: Robert Brandom (1950-), analytic philosopher working in pragmatist and inferentialist traditions, argues that conceptual content is constituted by inferential roles—what follows from a claim and what would be evidence for it. His framework is essential here because it makes explicit how vocabulary choices commit authors to entire networks of inference, and how tracing these commitment-patterns reveals intellectual formation. Brandom's notion of vocabulary as conferring expressive power explains why certain theoretical terms become indispensable tools that mark lineage.
secondary.name: brandom

secondary.description: Ernst Cassirer (1874-1945), neo-Kantian philosopher and historian of ideas, analyzed how symbolic forms and conceptual schemes structure experience across domains from myth to mathematics. His approach to conceptual history as the evolution of organizing categories informs this engine's attention to how analytical frameworks migrate across disciplinary boundaries and how metaphorical structures do genuine cognitive work rather than mere illustration. Cassirer's method of tracking concept-transformation through intellectual history provides the genealogical depth this engine requires.
secondary.name: cassirer

traditions.description: The Lakatosian methodology analyzing scientific theories as research programmes with persistent hard cores (unfalsifiable commitments), protective belts (auxiliary hypotheses), and positive/negative heuristics (methodological directives for theory development). This tradition informs the engine's approach to identifying the stable analytical commitments that survive across an author's work while peripheral frameworks mutate, and to recognizing methodological signatures as expressions of deeper programmatic commitments rather than isolated choices.
traditions.name: research_programmes

traditions.description: The Kuhnian approach to understanding scientific communities through their shared paradigms—exemplary problem-solutions, disciplinary matrices, and symbolic generalizations that define normal science. For this engine, paradigm analysis provides the lens for understanding how analytical frameworks function as gestalt-determining structures: they don't just organize existing observations but determine what counts as an observation, what puzzles are worth solving, and what forms solutions must take. This tradition emphasizes the pre-theoretical commitments embedded in methodological choices.
traditions.name: paradigm_analysis

traditions.description: The Brandomian philosophical program treating conceptual content as constituted by patterns of inference rather than by reference or representation—what commitments a claim licenses, what would count as evidence, what follows from accepting it. This tradition gives the engine its approach to vocabulary analysis: terms are not merely labels but nodes in inferential networks, and tracking an author's characteristic inferences reveals their conceptual commitments. It makes explicit how framework choices determine evidential standards and argumentative validity.
traditions.name: inferentialism

traditions.description: The tradition (Begriffsgeschichte) of tracing how fundamental concepts evolve through intellectual history, carrying sedimented meanings and enabling or constraining new thought. Practiced by figures from Cassirer to Koselleck, it treats concepts as historical actors that bear the weight of their past uses while being reconfigured for new analytical work. This tradition informs the engine's genealogical orientation: every theoretical term has a history, and an author's relationship to that history—whether they innovate, inherit, or hybridize—is itself genealogically significant.
traditions.name: conceptual_history

traditions.description: The practice of treating terminological choices as intellectually consequential, revealing theoretical commitments, disciplinary training, and lineage relationships. Drawing from Brandom's inferentialism and Kuhn's theory-ladenness of observation terms, this tradition holds that vocabularies are not neutral description-tools but frameworks that make certain questions askable and certain answers possible. For this engine, vocabulary analysis is the primary technique for identifying both explicit frameworks and tacit commitments—the terms that need no justification in the text reveal what authority the author assumes.
traditions.name: vocabulary_analysis

problematique:
Every intellectual work is built on a scaffolding of analytical
frameworks -- theoretical models, typologies, causal stories,
analytical lenses -- that structure what can be seen, what counts
as evidence, and what conclusions are reachable. But frameworks
are not just tools of analysis; they are themselves carriers of
intellectual history. An author's vocabulary reveals their training.
Their methodological signature -- how they characteristically argue --
persists across decades, mutating but recognizable. Their metaphors
do real analytical work, not just decoration, and the metaphors that
migrate from one work to the next are genealogy gold: tracers
revealing intellectual lineage.

This engine extracts the full conceptual architecture of a work:
the frameworks deployed, the vocabulary introduced or repurposed,
the methodological habits that structure argumentation, the metaphors
that carry analytical weight, and the framing choices that foreground
some aspects while rendering others invisible. It asks not just
"what frameworks are used?" but "what does the choice and handling
of these frameworks reveal about the author's intellectual formation?"

The genealogical dimension is central. Terms that feel established
but are not justified in the current text alone -- they rely on
authority accumulated elsewhere. Methodological moves that feel
habitual -- they trace back years, sometimes decades. Metaphors
doing heavy analytical lifting -- they probably evolved from simpler
forms in earlier work. These are the threads that downstream engines
(semantic constellation, inferential commitment mapper) will pull on.

As the FIRST engine in the target profiling chain, this engine
produces the foundational profile that all subsequent analysis
builds upon. Its vocabulary map becomes the search targets for
semantic constellation mapping. Its commitment landscape feeds
the inferential commitment mapper. Get this profile wrong, and
the entire genealogical analysis inherits the distortion.
researcher_question: What analytical frameworks structure thinking in this collection?
